book.name: Session 3: Integrated Basic Skills and Career Pathways

chapter.title: Emphasizing integrated basic skills and career pathways
chapter.content:
Emphasizing integrated basic skills and career pathways

Let’s now discuss instructional programs and approaches that emphasize integrated basic skills and career pathways.

As discussed earlier, trends in the current economy have created a need for workers who are able to perform basic literacy tasks and who have strong skills in the areas of communication, problem-solving, and teamwork. It is a monumental task, however, for instructors to both:

  • help to meet the needs of employers for skilled technical workers, and

  • provide for the literacy and skills remediation of adult learners who hope to gain and maintain suitable employment and self-sufficiency.

Research indicates that contextual learning shows promise for adult learners. There is also evidence of a link between literacy and earnings. The Time for the U.S. to Reskill? report includes recommendations for increased efforts to link the improvement of basic skills to employability, such as through instructional programs and approaches that emphasize integrated basic skills and career pathways.

chapter.title: Career pathways
chapter.content:
Career pathways

While there are a number of definitions of career pathways, a 2012 joint letter of the U.S. Departments of Education, and Health and Human Services, describes this term as:

 “…a series of connected education and training strategies and support services that enable individuals to secure industry relevant certification and obtain employment within an occupational area and to advance to higher levels of future education and employment in that area.”

In May 2016, an updated letter of continued commitment to career pathways systems development was signed by 12 Federal agencies. This letter updates the definition for career pathways to align more closely with the Workforce Innovation and Opportunities Act of 2014 (WIOA), reiterates the six key elements of a career pathways system, and provides updated tools and resources from the expanded group of Federal agency partners.

 The Workforce Innovation and Opportunity Act provides a common definition of career pathways for the education and workforce system.

The term “career pathway” means a combination of rigorous and high-quality education, training, and other services that –

A.  aligns with the skill needs of industries in the economy of the State or regional
     economy involved;

B.  prepares an individual to be successful in any of a full range of secondary or
     postsecondary options, including apprenticeships;

C.  includes counseling to support an individual in achieving the individual’s education
     and career goals;

D.  includes, as appropriate, education offered concurrently with and in the same
     context as workforce preparation activities and training for a specific
     occupation or occupational cluster;

E.  organizes education, training, and other services to meet the particular needs of an
     individual in a manner that accelerates the educational and career advancement of
     the individual to the extent practicable;

F.  enables an individual to attain a secondary school diploma or its recognized
     equivalent, and at least one recognized postsecondary credential; and

G.  helps an individual enter or advance within a specific occupation or
     occupational cluster. [Section 3(7) of WIOA]

chapter.title: Integrated basic skills
chapter.content:
Integrated basic skills

In this approach, career-technical instructors team with ABE/GED instructors and ESL instructors. Instructors focus on specific occupational skills training (for example: plumbing, mechanics, landscaping, etc.) while concurrently providing literacy education to ABE/GED students, including those who are English Language Learners. Instructors work as a team and the basic skills are taught within the context of a particular career area.

 

 

Click the forward arrow to learn about integrating the career pathways approach into your instruction.

chapter.title: Objectives of career pathways courses
chapter.content:
Objectives of career pathways courses

Career pathways are intended to help individuals develop career plans that they can explore and connect to their academic and occupational education and interests. For educators, they provide a means of developing and organizing curricula across 16 different career clusters.

The objectives of career pathways course offerings are to:

  • help students understand and consider career options;

  • discover workplaces and their relationship to curricula;

  • make choices about future education and training; and

  • understand the expectations for achieving career goals, maintain portfolios of progress and achievement, and to become flexible but focused employees.

chapter.title: The LINCS Resource Collection
chapter.content:
The LINCS Resource Collection

The LINCS Resource Collection includes a large library of online instructional materials and resources related to work readiness, workforce education and career pathways for adult learners in ABE/GED programs. You may also explore other resources housed on LINCS specific to Adult Career Pathways.

chapter.title: Career clusters
chapter.content:
Career clusters

The U.S. Department of Labor has laid out guidelines to group occupations into career clusters based on broad industry commonalities. Career clusters can help prepare learners for higher education and careers by providing them with relevant contexts for learning and linking what they learned in school to the knowledge and skills needed for a successful career. Connecting education to future career goals can help motivate learners.

Many resources are organized according to these career clusters or occupational categories that define the skills and knowledge needed to work in particular industries. These are often good resources to use when developing instructional material.

Let’s examine some career clusters in more detail.

chapter.title: 16 Career clusters
chapter.content:
16 Career clusters

The 16 Career Clusters are:

  • Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources;
  • Architecture and Construction;
  • Arts, AV Technology, and Communication;
  • Business Management and Administration;
  • Education and Training;
  • Finance;
  • Government and Public Administration;
  • Health Science;
  • Hospitality and Tourism;
  • Human Services;
  • Information Technology;
  • Law, Public Safety, Corrections, and Security;
  • Manufacturing;
  • Marketing, Sales, and Service;
  • Science, Engineering, Information Technology; and
  • Transportation, Distribution, and Logistics.

chapter.title: Other occupational groupings
chapter.content:
Other occupational groupings

The U.S. Department of Labor does not limit itself, however, to just the 16 career clusters framework.

Other currently used occupational groupings include:

  • Bright Outlook – occupations that are expected to grow rapidly in the next several years, will have large numbers of job openings, or are new and emerging occupations.

  • Green Jobs – occupations connected to or affected by environmentally conscious industry efforts and economic sectors.

  • Job Families – groups of occupations based upon work performed, skills, education, training, and credentials.

  • Industry groups – broad groups of businesses or organizations with similar activities, products, or services.

  • STEM occupations – occupations that require education in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) disciplines.

Regardless of the preferred grouping, however, the mynextmove.org and O-NET OnLine resources can assist learners to explore job possibilities and create career plans based on their needs and interests.

chapter.title: Activity: Integrating the career pathways approach
chapter.content:
Activity: Integrating the career pathways approach

Now we ask you to consider for a moment, how could you integrate the career pathways approach into your work with adult learners with LD? 

When you have generated one or more ideas, click the forward arrow for some suggestions you might want to consider.

chapter.title: Ideas for integrating the career pathways approach
chapter.content:
Ideas for integrating the career pathways approach

Ideas for incorporating the career pathways approach into instruction for adults with LD will vary, but here are some examples:

Instructors can help students to:

  • link interests and aptitudes to specific career areas; 
  • explore the types of skills and training needed for certain careers; and
  • create an educational plan for a particular career pathway.

chapter.title: Activity: Share your thoughts and ideas in the discussion forum
chapter.content:
Activity: Share your thoughts and ideas in the discussion forum

We’ve discussed instructional strategies instructors can use to help adults with LD develop skills that will support success at each phase of the employment process.

Please take a few moments to consider the examples presented. Then answer the following questions:

  • Have you used any of the ideas presented in your classroom instruction? 
  • What other strategies, activities, and methods have you used to help adults with LD develop skills that will support success at each phase of the employment process?
  • Which ones seem to be the most effective?
  • How do you know?

Please share your reflections and ideas, and read other teachers’ responses in the LINCS Disabilities in Adult Education Group before moving on.

 

When you have finished posting your ideas, click the up arrow to return to the course home page and expand the Guiding Question #2 header bar.
